SENT.plain: The aim of this study was to determine the correlation between microsatellite instability (MSI) and young age in patients with advanced colorectal adenomas
We retrospectively analyzed young patients (≤ 40 years of age) with advanced adenomas (n=84) between January 1996 and December 2006
We randomly selected the control group as patients ≥ 50 years of age with advanced adenomas (n=84) during the same time period
Of these patients, the MSI test and MLH1 immunohistochemistry were performed in the available tissue samples from patients with advanced adenomas
The number of patients who had the two tests was 52 in the young group and 49 in the old group
The monomorphic nature of the BAT26 panel for MSI analysis was used without comparison of normal tissue
MSI was detected in three young patients (n=52) and none of the old patients (n=49)
There was no statistical difference between the two groups (P=0.243)
All three young patients with MSI had a strong family history of colorectal cancer
MSI analysis was not a useful method of screening for HNPCC in young patients with advanced colorectal adenoma, at least in cases without a family history of colorectal cancer
